thread.title: German beer and French wine to be removed from Wetherspoons menu due to Brexit

author: Simon Meechan
title: German beer and French wine to be removed from Wetherspoons menu due to Brexit
text:
German beer and French wine to be removed from Wetherspoons menu due to Brexit The pub chain is replacing EU manufactured alcohol with booze from Britain and around the world Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get what's on updates
Wetherspoons is removing EU-brewed drinks from its bar in the run up to Brexit.
The pub chain will swap French champagnes and German-brewed beers for British and Australian products as the United Kingdom prepares to leave the European Union.
Customers will start to notice the changes from July 9.
Chairman Tim Martin - who publicly backed Brexi t - claims the change will lead to an ‘improved offer’ for Spoons’ two million weekly customers.
However, the bars will still serve some EU brands, as Wetherspoons is honouring existing contracts and deals with breweries, some of which have years to run. But Mr Martin says the business is shifting to "non-EU trade".
Mr Martin said: “It is the start of a review all products in the next six to 24 months, with the object of making our business more competitive.
“The EU’s customs union is a protectionist system which is widely misunderstood.
“It imposes tariffs on the 93% of the world that is not in the EU, keeping prices high for UK consumers.
“Tariffs are imposed on wine from Australia, New Zealand and the US, and also on coffee, oranges, rice and more than 12,000 other products." It's out with German beer and French champagne at Wetherspoons
“There will be an inevitable transfer of trade post-Brexit to countries outside the EU, which will reduce prices in shops and pubs.
“The products we are now introducing are at lower prices than the EU products they are replacing.
“We intend to honour existing contracts with EU suppliers, some of which have several years to run.
“However, we are starting to make the transition to non-EU trade now.” Read More Wetherspoon's has launched its first wedding venue - although you'll have to travel
French sparkling wine will be swapped for British versions, such as Denbies Sparkling Whitedowns Brut and Whitedowns Rose Brut.
A spokesman told ChronicleLive that Wetherspoons will still offer Italian prosecco , which is extremely popular with customers, although the company will review its wine list over the next 24 months.
Spoons will also stock more British wheat beers like Blue Moon Belgian White, Thornbridge Versa Weisse Beer and SA Brains Atlantic White.
However, Sweden’s Kopparberg will still be sold by the pub chain, as the cider will be produced in Britain after Brexit.
